comment.author: 8892367@N05
comment._content: See a blog post featuring this photograph on THE BIGGER PICTURE: blog.photography.si.edu/2010/02/03/new-donation-of-scopes...

comment.author: 61436794@N00
comment._content: Love to look at history and our past (same thing?). Makes you wonder where their lifes went and how they lived. Very cool!

comment.author: 47696510@N02
comment._content: If anyone can help. we would like to identify William Silverman's high school teacher on the left.  Silverman graduated from Chattanooga High School in 1922 so a yearbook might help.

comment.author: 21686909@N07
comment._content: Smithsonian, when you set your tag, put "Smithsonian Institution" in quotes otherwise it is tagged as the two separate words.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: Thanks for pointing that out, budderflyman. Something was 'off' in our upload script.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: We're looking for your help! Please help us identify the unnamed in this photograph in the comments below. This photo is featured in a post on the Smithsonian Institution Archives' blog, THE BIGGER PICTURE.

comment.author: 91971452@N08
comment._content:
The science teacher in the photo taught at Chattaooga High School. His photo is likely in the 1925 edition of the school yearbook. The school was contacted more than once to see if someone could check the yearbook but there has been no response.
One problem may be that that school no longer exists as it was. It is now a magnet school called Chattanooga High School Center for Creative Arts.

comment.author: 25053835@N03
comment._content: We can now positively say that William Silverman's teacher is Creed F. Bates, Jr. due to the detective work of Silverman's daughter, Henrietta Jenrette. Thank you, Henrietta!

comment.author: 91971452@N08
comment._content: The yearbooks of Chattanooga High School in 1922 and 1925 showed that Creed F. Bates, Jr. was a teacher of modern languages, not science,  until he became principal of the school in 1925.
